column1: Włocławek [vwɔt͡sˈwavɛk] (listen) (German: Leslau) is a city located in central Poland along the Vistula (Wisła) River and is bordered by the Gostynin-Włocławek Landscape Park. As of December 2019
column2: the population of the city is 109
column4: it was the capital of Włocławek Voivodeship until 1999.

column1: The city is located in the historical region of Kuyavia and is the region's second largest city after Bydgoszcz.

Włocławek's history dates back to the late Bronze Age – early Iron Age (1300 BCE – 500 BCE). Archaeological excavations conducted on the current city site uncovered the remains of a settlement belonging to the Lausitz culture
column2: as well as evidence of a settlement of early Pomeranian culture which had been established. Traces of additional settlements dating to the Roman period and the early Middle Ages have also been excavated in the area.

column1: Precise dating of the city's founding has proven difficult. Since the 16th century
column2: there is conflicting data in relation to the establishment of the town. The confusion lies with varying attributions of the city's name (which was derived from the first name Władysław
column3: or Vladislav) and its subsequent rulers; Władysław II the Exile
column4: (Polish: Władysław II Wygnaniec) (1105 – 30 May 1159) a High Duke of Poland and Duke of Silesia from 1138 until his expulsion in 1146. His grandfather Władysław I Herman
column5: or Vladislav II of Bohemia. Civil war between these generations
column6: due to a royal title granted as a lifetime honorific from Holy Roman Emperor
column7: but did not provide for a hereditary monarchy. This resulted in church reformations and a lack of documentation for the area.

column1: One of the earliest references to the town came from an assistant to the Archbishop of Gniezno who was noted as residing in the town in 1123. Later the Diocese of Włocławek (Latin: Vladislaviensis) of Kuyavia in 1148
column2: notates its existence in a bull issued by Pope Eugene III
column3: while mentioning the first bishop of Włocławek as Warner. Warner was followed by an Italian
column4: Onoldius; the diocese was recorded as "Włocławek and Pomerania" (Vladislaviensis et Pomeraniae).

column1: Włocławek received its town rights in 1255. During the 14th and 15th centuries
column2: the city was destroyed and captured several times by the Teutonic Knights and renamed it Leslau. The Treaty of Thorn
column4: resulted in short-lived peace for the city
column6: it prospered from its involvement in the ransoming of the captured Teutonic Knights which was payable in three instalments and proved to be a hardship on the Prussian faction. Włocławek was located within the Brześć Kujawski Voivodeship of the Greater Poland Province of the Polish Crown.

column2: Bishop Stanisław Karnkowski founded a theological seminary in Włocławek
column3: one of the oldest seminaries in Poland.During the Swedish invasion of 1657
column4: Second Northern War
column5: the city was partially destroyed. After the Second Partition of Poland of 1793
column6: Włocławek became part of Prussia. After the Treaties of Tilsit in 1807 it became part of the Polish short-lived Duchy of Warsaw. Subsequently
column7: after the Congress of Vienna it became part of Congress Poland
column8: but the city was later occupied by the Russian Empire in 1831. The oldest Polish theological journal Ateneum Kapłańskie has been published in Włocławek since 1909. The city was again destroyed during the battles of German offensive during the First World War. After Poland declared independence in 1918
column9: Włocławek was reintegrated into Polish territory. In 1920
column10: Poles successfully defended the city against the invading Soviets during the Polish–Soviet War.

column2: Włocławek was occupied by German troops
column3: which entered the city on 14 September 1939. Under the Nazi German occupation Włocławek was again renamed Leslau
column4: annexed by decree to the German Reich on 8 October 1939 and administered from 26 October as a part of Reichsgau Posen (renamed on 29 January 1940 Reichsgau Wartheland).

column2: Germans committed a massacre of a group of local Jews and burned both synagogues. By the time the war ended
column3: nearly the entire Jewish population of more than 10
column4: 000 had been murdered.  The Einsatzgruppe III entered the city between September 23 and October 5
column6: and afterwards carried out mass arrests of local Poles in October and November as part of the Intelligenzaktion. Dozens of Catholic priests from Włocławek
column7: including Auxiliary Bishop of Włocławek Michał Kozal
column8: and lecturers and students of the seminary were arrested
column9: and then deported in January 1940 to the Dachau concentration camp
column10: where most of them were killed. Rector of the local seminary Henryk Kaczorowski and two students Bronisław Kostkowski and Tadeusz Dulny are now considered three of the 108 Blessed Polish Martyrs of World War II by the Catholic Church. Local teachers were arrested in October 1939
column11: and then deported to Nazi concentration camps and murdered. In late 1939
column12: the SS and Selbstschutz burnt down the Grzywno district and murdered many of its inhabitants in the nearby village of Warząchewka Polska. Poles from Włocławek were also massacred in the nearby village of Pińczata. Arrested Polish teachers
column13: landowners and priests from the Włocławek and Lipno counties were also imprisoned in Włocławek
column14: and some were later also deported to concentration camps and murdered.Families of deported and murdered Poles
column15: as well as the remaining residents of Grzywno were expelled to the so-called General Government in late 1939
column16: and in 1940 also owners of shops
column17: workshops and bigger houses were expelled
column18: so their properties could be handed over to German colonists as part of the Lebensraum policy. The Germans also robbed the precious historical collections of the Diocese of Włocławek and closed down the cathedral. The city's central square
column20: was renamed Adolf-Hitler-Platz by the Germans.

column1: Włocławek was liberated on 20 January 1945 by Soviet troops of the 1st Belorussian Front during the Vistula–Oder Offensive. One third of the city was destroyed
column2: but its factories and workshops were rebuilt by the Polish government in the following decades.

The Jewish population increased from 218 (6.6%) in 1820 to 6

column9: Włocławek became the first town in Europe in which Jews were required to wear distinctive yellow badges. Murders of Jews began in 1939 and the Włocławek ghetto was created in November 1940. The Nazis deported 3
column10: 000 of Włocławek's Jews to ghettos and labor camps between December 1939 and June 1941. Some 2
column11: 000 Jews were deported to Łódź and then to the Chełmno extermination camp between 26 and 30 September 1941. The ghetto was burnt in late April 1942 after the remaining Jews were sent to Chelmno where they were immediately gassed. Most of the Jews sent to the Łódź Ghetto died of starvation or illness
column12: and many were sent to Auschwitz from Łódź.After the war nearly 1000 Jews returned to Włocławek and re-established their community. However
